sections.title: Dental crowns
sections.body:
A dental crown is used when a tooth needs more protection than a filling can provide.

Crowns are most often recommended for teeth that are heavily worn, cracked, weakened, or have already had extensive treatment. The aim is to protect what remains of the tooth and help it function comfortably for the long term.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, crowns are planned carefully, not routinely.
bullets: Protection for heavily worn or weakened teeth
Designed to preserve healthy tooth where possible

sections.title: When a crown may be recommended
items: A tooth is badly broken or worn
A large filling has failed or is likely to fail
A tooth has been root-treated
Cracks affect strength or comfort
Long-term protection is needed

sections.title: Our approach to crowns
sections.body:
Crowns aren’t just about covering a tooth.

We focus on preserving as much natural tooth as possible, choosing designs that support the tooth rather than over-cutting it, planning the bite carefully to reduce stress, and aiming for longevity rather than quick cosmetic fixes.

sections.label: Digital planning
sections.title: Scans that guide fit, bite, and appearance
sections.body: Intraoral scans capture your bite and neighbouring teeth so the lab can produce a crown with clean margins, comfortable contacts, and a shade that blends. This reduces chairside adjustments and helps the crown feel natural from the first fit.

sections.title: Appointments designed for calm, clear communication
items: Local anaesthetic options explained before any preparation
Gentle isolation and support for patients with gag reflex or anxiety
Temporary coverage smoothed for comfort while the final crown is made
Regular bite checks during fitting to avoid high spots
Clear aftercare guidance and easy contact if anything feels unfamiliar

sections.title: When a crown isn’t the best option
sections.body:
Crowns aren’t always the answer.

In some situations, alternatives such as fillings, onlays, or monitoring may be more appropriate. If we think a crown isn’t the best long-term solution, we’ll explain our reasoning clearly.

sections.title: What to expect from crown treatment

faqs.question: Who is a suitable candidate for a crown?
faqs.answer: Crowns are recommended when a tooth is cracked, heavily filled, or needs reinforcement after root canal treatment. If a more conservative option is viable, we will explain that first.

faqs.question: Are there alternatives to a crown?
faqs.answer: Depending on remaining tooth structure, options may include an onlay, bonded repair, or monitoring. We map crack risk and bite forces to advise when full coverage is the safer route.

faqs.question: How long will my crown last?
faqs.answer: Durability depends on bite forces, hygiene, and material. We choose ceramics or metal-ceramic options to suit your case and schedule reviews to check margins and contacts over time.

faqs.question: What maintenance does a crown need?
faqs.answer: Clean carefully around the margins and attend regular hygiene appointments. Bite checks help us refine contacts and spot early signs of wear or gum inflammation.

faqs.question: What are the risks or limitations?
faqs.answer: Crowns can chip, loosen, or develop decay at the margins if hygiene or bite balance is poor. We plan coverage height and consider splints if grinding is present to reduce these risks.

faqs.question: How are crowns priced?
faqs.answer: Fees vary by material, laboratory input, and any additional planning such as scan-guided design. We provide a written estimate and outline phased treatment if needed.

faqs.question: Will the crown match my other teeth?
faqs.answer: We shade-map your neighbouring teeth and use digital scans to guide shape and translucency. The aim is a natural blend that suits your smile and gumline.
